quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Get clear on your objective function, and one way that I've gotten clear on it is trying to think about it from future me because five years from now, I'm not going to give a if I made the presentation slightly better, but I'm going to care a lot about what kind of relationship I have with my daughters, and that means that the next action, the next thing I do today and tomorrow, those will translate into the relationship with her, right?
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A practical prioritization framework: use “future you” to define your objective function and choose actions that compound into what you’ll actually value.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Not to be morbid, but just again, most of us just aren't really tuned into an awareness that our lives will come to an end.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A counterintuitive leadership lens: mortality awareness as a tool to recalibrate priorities and attention.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: And the horror of it is that we succeed, right? We mostly manage to just go live our life and eat ice cream and go to work and go on vacation and do what we do.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A memorable observation about how default living can crowd out intentional choices unless actively challenged.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: To me, an awareness and mindfulness that our lives will come to an end punctuates reality in a way that requires me to rethink my priorities.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: Actionable advice: use mindfulness of finitude to force a periodic reset of what you’re optimizing for.

quotes.topic_title: Defining conscious leadership and influence
quotes.text: To me, leadership is broadly defined as having influence in the world, and so by that definition, to me, everyone is a leader because we all have influence in some way.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: Reframes leadership as universal influence rather than a formal role, expanding who should practice leadership skills.

quotes.topic_title: Defining conscious leadership and influence
quotes.text: It's not about whether you're a manager or not, it's like I have influence on my kids or my partner or my community, or the world, the way I vote, the way I show up.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: Gives concrete examples of everyday influence, making leadership actionable beyond the workplace.

quotes.topic_title: Defining conscious leadership and influence
quotes.text: The conscious piece then is becoming more aware, waking up.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: Defines consciousness as an active practice of awareness, setting up a simple mental model for “conscious leadership.”

quotes.topic_title: Defining conscious leadership and influence
quotes.text: We all inherit certain belief systems from our parents or our church or our community, and a lot of times they kind of go unquestioned and then they end up in conflict.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: Highlights inherited, unexamined beliefs as a root cause of conflict—pointing to self-inquiry as a leadership lever.

quotes.topic_title: Defining conscious leadership and influence
quotes.text: And so it's really just about becoming more aware and then taking responsibility for the influence that I have.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: Turns awareness into accountability, emphasizing responsibility for impact as the core practice.

quotes.topic_title: Soft skills, power dynamics, and creating space
quotes.text: I think when I was younger in my career, I thought it was really important that we got to show up to the meeting and have the right slides and be the loudest, rightest voice in the room, and that's the way to have influence.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: Highlights a common early-career (often flawed) model of influence that practitioners can consciously move beyond.

quotes.topic_title: Soft skills, power dynamics, and creating space
quotes.text: It's also as I've become a more senior leader, I'm aware that there are power dynamics there. There's imbalances where junior folks don't feel as comfortable speaking up or I say something's not a good idea and then, "Well, I don't want to disagree with J.M."
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A concrete reminder that senior leaders' opinions can unintentionally silence dissent, requiring active mitigation.

quotes.topic_title: Soft skills, power dynamics, and creating space
quotes.text: I really try to spend more time being mindful of that and say, I want to hear from other people first. I want to create space and I don't need to win the argument in the meeting.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: Actionable meeting behavior: invite others to speak first and prioritize psychological safety over “winning.”

quotes.topic_title: Soft skills, power dynamics, and creating space
quotes.text: There can be a follow-up. It's not like this is my last chance to say something, but that's also more true when you're more senior because when you're more junior, it's like, well, this is the one presentation I have with Dara for the next six months. I really got to nail it.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: Explains why juniors may over-optimize for a single high-stakes moment, while seniors can create space by deferring to follow-ups.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Tired of bouncing around multiple tools to uncover what's really happening inside your product? With all the tools you need in one simple to use platform, Pendo makes it easy to answer critical questions about how users are engaging with your product and then turn those insights into action.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights an actionable workflow: consolidate tooling to understand user behavior and convert insights into product changes.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: First, Pendo is built around product analytics, seeing what your users are actually doing in your apps so that you can optimize their experience. Next, Pendo lets you deploy in-app guides that lead users through the actions that matter most. Then Pendo integrates user feedback so that you can capture and analyze what people actually want.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Provides a practical three-part product experience loop: observe behavior, guide key actions, and incorporate feedback.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And the new thing in Pendo, session replace, a very cool way to visualize user sessions. I'm not surprised at all that over 10,000 companies use it today.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Offers a concrete example (session visualization) plus a credibility data point ("over 10,000 companies").

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you're a founder, exec, product manager or engineer tasked with the enterprise roadmap, this conference is for you. You'll get detailed insights from industry leaders that have years of experience navigating the same challenges that you face today. And best of all, it's completely free since it's hosted by WorkOS.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Actionable recommendation for practitioners building enterprise features: learn directly from experienced operators, with a notable “free” access point.

quotes.topic_title: Uber culture across eras and inner work
quotes.text: You're right, it was like many organizations that run on fear because you can do that, carrots and sticks do work.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A candid, counterintuitive acknowledgment that fear-based incentives can be effective—useful for leaders diagnosing what’s actually driving performance (and its costs).

quotes.topic_title: Uber culture across eras and inner work
quotes.text: And that's kind of what led me to start to explore this sort of inner work and meditation and sort of finding a way out of that.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: Connects personal stress in high-intensity environments to a practical intervention (inner work/meditation) as a way to regain resilience and effectiveness.

quotes.topic_title: Uber culture across eras and inner work
quotes.text: I don't think this conversation actually needs another PhD, or I'm not even PhD, but content expert.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A memorable heuristic for meetings: when teams are stuck, more expertise may not help—what’s needed is a shift in group dynamics/state.

quotes.topic_title: Uber culture across eras and inner work
quotes.text: It's like what we need here is a way to shift again, back out of that fear, threat, righteousness sort of state into a more co-creative, collaborative, open-minded, curious, trusting sort of space.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: Offers a practical mental model for facilitation: recognize “fear/threat/righteousness” and intentionally move the team into a “co-creative” state.

quotes.topic_title: Uber culture across eras and inner work
quotes.text: So now I would say we're in Uber 3.0, which it's full pirate ship to navy, in Reid Hoffman's words, a profitable company.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A clear stage-based framing (“Uber 3.0”) plus the “pirate ship to navy” metaphor for how companies evolve from scrappy to operationally mature.

quotes.topic_title: Naming UberX and Uber Pool
quotes.text: One quick tangent, UberX, a previous guest shared that the name UberX came from... it was just like the internal code name, UberX, we'll figure out a real name later, and then it stuck and no one had a better name. Is that true?
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete example of how internal codenames can become permanent product names when teams move fast and no better alternative emerges.

quotes.topic_title: Naming UberX and Uber Pool
quotes.text: Yeah, that's right. I think that's right.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: Confirms the codename-to-brand dynamic as a real phenomenon at Uber, reinforcing the takeaway for practitioners.

quotes.topic_title: Naming UberX and Uber Pool
quotes.text: But I did help name Uber Pool, Uber Pool, which I selflessly like to bring back. It got renamed to Share during my external APM rotation.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: Specific naming ownership plus an example of later rebranding, illustrating how product names can evolve with positioning and org changes.

quotes.topic_title: Allowing emotions to break stress loops
quotes.text: You can't. Don't try to stop the thought. Just allow it.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A practical instruction for handling intrusive thoughts by allowing them rather than trying to suppress them.

quotes.topic_title: Allowing emotions to break stress loops
quotes.text: I said, "Don't think of a pink elephant. What did you just think of?"
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A vivid example showing how thought-suppression backfires and makes the unwanted thought more salient.

quotes.topic_title: Allowing emotions to break stress loops
quotes.text: one of my first coaches actually had a great phrase, what you resist will persist and what you fear will appear.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A memorable, counterintuitive principle that reframes resistance as the mechanism that keeps anxiety alive.

quotes.topic_title: Allowing emotions to break stress loops
quotes.text: that can become a self-enforcing negative feedback loop where I have a thought that creates stress, anxiety, fear, and then that triggers more thoughts and we call it cognitive emotive loop
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A named mental model for how thoughts and emotions reinforce each other, clarifying what needs to be interrupted.

quotes.topic_title: Allowing emotions to break stress loops
quotes.text: And so one way to break that is to just allow it and not try to fight it with other thoughts.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A concrete technique for breaking the stress loop by dropping the internal argument and letting feelings pass.

quotes.topic_title: Self-worth beyond approval, control, and security
quotes.text: Well, that would be the first step, is just to allow whatever's here, thoughts and emotions are rising. They come, they go, they're transient. It's not permanent.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A practical in-the-moment regulation tactic: notice and allow emotions/thoughts without fighting them, remembering they pass.

quotes.topic_title: Self-worth beyond approval, control, and security
quotes.text: I don't actually need Dara to approve of me in my presentation in order to be okay.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframe that decouples performance from self-worth, reducing anxiety in high-status rooms.

quotes.topic_title: Self-worth beyond approval, control, and security
quotes.text: So we talk about approval, control and security. It's very easy to look for that from the world. Do you approve of me? And if not, can I control outcomes to get approval or get security and get the job, the bank account, the house, whatever it is?
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A memorable framework (“approval, control and security”) for diagnosing what you’re really chasing when you feel threatened.

quotes.topic_title: Self-worth beyond approval, control, and security
quotes.text: But what I kind of woke up to at one point was that as long as I was going out there looking for all that stuff to try to complete something inside of me that was missing, it's like I was a hungry ghost.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A vivid mental model (“hungry ghost”) for why external achievements can’t permanently resolve internal insecurity.

quotes.topic_title: Self-worth beyond approval, control, and security
quotes.text: Whereas if I'm in that trusting, curious, open space, it's like this is an opportunity for feedback. How can I learn? How can I get to become a better presenter? It's like the feedback from others is no longer a threat. It's actually a gift.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A shift from threat-response to learning mode that turns feedback into usable input rather than a career-ending verdict.

quotes.topic_title: Optics versus impact and purpose-driven work
quotes.text: what I found was the more I focused on how I show up and optics and having a good deck and all this, the less I got promoted and then the more I dropped focusing all that.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: Contrarian observation that over-optimizing for optics can backfire on career progression, while focusing on the work can accelerate it.

quotes.topic_title: Optics versus impact and purpose-driven work
quotes.text: it's like, you know what? I am here to be a conduit from what wants to happen in the world of transportation and mobility and shared rides is one that I've always been particularly passionate about, so that's a good example, and then how can I get present and listen to what wants to happen next in the world of shared rides?
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A purpose-driven mental model for product work: treat yourself as a conduit and listen for what the domain “wants” next rather than leading with ego.

quotes.topic_title: Optics versus impact and purpose-driven work
quotes.text: it's really about, I want to make a fucking awesome product, right?
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A simple, memorable north star that reorients decisions away from self-image and toward product impact.

quotes.topic_title: Optics versus impact and purpose-driven work
quotes.text: But those are a means to a more powerful and transformative end than just my career.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: Reframes communication/presentation as instrumental (not the goal), helping practitioners reduce anxiety and focus on outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Optics versus impact and purpose-driven work
quotes.text: don't mistake the finger pointing at the moon for the moon.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A sticky metaphor for not confusing artifacts (decks/OKRs/optics) with the real objective (product and impact).

quotes.topic_title: Building strategy and vision through immersion
quotes.text: So step one is, am I working at a place and in a product area in which I have a tremendous amount of passion? Because for me, that is the fuel and the motivation that helps me break through to getting the strategy.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A practical prerequisite for strategy work: pick a domain you genuinely care about because it supplies the energy needed to do deep thinking.

quotes.topic_title: Building strategy and vision through immersion
quotes.text: And then the next thing I guess that's been helpful is I've deeply immersed myself. I haven't really jumped around between crypto and gen AI, this stuff, and a lot of people do that. It's great, nothing wrong with that, but I've been in this largely focused on mobility space for 10 years now with some stints over in the restaurant tech and delivery side, but very related in terms of last mile logistics.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A counterpoint to trend-hopping: long-term immersion in one domain compounds insight and improves strategic judgment.

quotes.topic_title: Building strategy and vision through immersion
quotes.text: I think it's hard to come up with a great strategy if you've only been working in an area for six months.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A blunt heuristic practitioners can use to calibrate expectations: strategy quality depends on time-in-domain.

quotes.topic_title: Building strategy and vision through immersion
quotes.text: One example might be, why do we need a 4,000 pound vehicle to move a human three miles?
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A first-principles prompt that reframes a problem via physics/efficiency, often revealing new product directions (e.g., micromobility).

quotes.topic_title: Building strategy and vision through immersion
quotes.text: My general thing is just like, yeah, that's the mountain thing is I try to just close my eyes and imagine the future as far out as I can.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A concrete method for generating vision: vivid future visualization as an input to strategy and narrative.

quotes.topic_title: Making space for deep thinking and co-creation
quotes.text: Yeah, it's not like something you can just schedule 30 minutes for in the middle of your day of packed OKR reviews and random one-on-ones and meetings.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: Challenges the common assumption that vision work fits into small calendar slots, implying it requires a different mode and setup.

quotes.topic_title: Making space for deep thinking and co-creation
quotes.text: And so I'm a big fan of carving out time, again, first for myself, a couple hours, whatever, where I can just get out of the day-to-day craziness and get into that head space of five, 10 years from now.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on creating the conditions for long-horizon thinking by intentionally separating it from operational churn.

quotes.topic_title: Making space for deep thinking and co-creation
quotes.text: We recently had an all-day Monday thing where eight of us came into the office to talk about future of marketplace, and it was super productive. It was like, laptops down, we're going to spend all day together on a whiteboard.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A concrete example of an effective co-creation format (all-day, small group, no laptops, whiteboard) practitioners can replicate.

quotes.topic_title: Making space for deep thinking and co-creation
quotes.text: It's like Pixar calls the brain trust.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: Introduces a recognizable methodology for structured riffing and feedback that teams can adopt for vision and strategy work.

quotes.topic_title: Making space for deep thinking and co-creation
quotes.text: And again, there's no judgment, there's no attachment to being right. They're in a co-creative sort of space where they're just like co-exploring and riffing with each other.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: Defines the operating principles that make “brain trust” sessions work—psychological safety and exploration over correctness.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Something I've started to do, which is hard, but I find really valuable is when I'm driving to not play anything on the radio, not listen to any podcasts, and it's so unnatural and it's like, oh, this is hard.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A practical habit for creating mental space and reducing constant input to improve thinking quality.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I don't want my brain to just go... you don't trust your brain to go to a place that's fun, but it always does.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation that boredom can reliably lead to interesting, enjoyable thoughts without external stimulation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: So I've been trying to do that, and that's such a simple thing to do. Just don't turn anything on.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable, easy-to-apply rule-of-thumb for building a reflective practice during everyday routines.

quotes.topic_title: Uber marketplace future: multi-supply and multi-demand
quotes.text: Something I've started to do, which is hard, but I find really valuable is when I'm driving to not play anything on the radio, not listen to any podcasts, and it's so unnatural and it's like, oh, this is hard.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Actionable practice for creating mental space that can lead to better ideas and strategic thinking.

quotes.topic_title: Uber marketplace future: multi-supply and multi-demand
quotes.text: Go on a hike where you don't listen to a podcast or music on your commute and see what happens. You might be surprised.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: Counterintuitive advice to reduce content consumption to unlock deeper reflection and creativity.

quotes.topic_title: Uber marketplace future: multi-supply and multi-demand
quotes.text: And one of the, I guess big ahas for us is as we move away from the, in some ways simpler world of UberX being the predominant product, which is it used to be pretty simple.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: Highlights a strategic inflection point: moving from a single dominant product to a more complex multi-product marketplace.

quotes.topic_title: Uber marketplace future: multi-supply and multi-demand
quotes.text: And so this future of multi-modality and on the both demand side and the supply side is what makes the marketplace even more complex and challenging to build.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A clear mental model for why Uber’s next marketplace era is harder: complexity compounds when both sides diversify.

quotes.topic_title: Uber marketplace future: multi-supply and multi-demand
quotes.text: And so it was kind of all this around, okay, well now that we have taxis in the platform and we have fleet providers and we're starting to add Waymos and Cruise and other things, we have to have a marketplace that's aware of those different types of supply and which one might be available for what trips and how to think about cost and quality and allocation of trips and all that.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: Concrete example of “multi-supply” and the resulting need for new allocation logic across cost, quality, and eligibility.

quotes.topic_title: Focus, productivity, and the three-things rule
quotes.text: at the micro level, back to kind of like defrag your day, don't just do the 20, 30 minute meetings on 20 different topics.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A practical productivity heuristic: protect depth by avoiding excessive context-switching across many small meetings.

quotes.topic_title: Focus, productivity, and the three-things rule
quotes.text: I don't have a to-do list of 20 things. I try to have a to-do list of three of the most important highest leverage things that could have impact broadly across the company and then try this, like you said, let that one top thing marinate and chew on it.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A concrete “three-things rule” for prioritization that emphasizes leverage and sustained thinking time.

quotes.topic_title: Focus, productivity, and the three-things rule
quotes.text: There's basically three things that I need to do next, and then there's just some random backlog that I can just scan through periodically and that's it. That gets you most of the way.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A minimalist alternative to complex productivity systems: focus on the next three actions plus a lightweight backlog.

quotes.topic_title: Focus, productivity, and the three-things rule
quotes.text: if it's in your head, you're screwed because it's like you're trying to keep track of stuff and be creative and come up with the future of transportation and remember to pick up something from the pharmacy. It's a recipe for disaster.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A memorable argument for externalizing tasks: mental load kills creative and strategic capacity.

quotes.topic_title: Focus, productivity, and the three-things rule
quotes.text: This whole idea of empty mind, beginner's mind, well, you have to empty the mind of all the to-dos first. Just get that out of the head.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A clear mental model linking “beginner’s mind” to a concrete practice: offload to-dos to create cognitive space.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing vision and execution in practice
quotes.text: Yeah, I think you can go too far either direction, right? It's like everything in life is about balancing the polarity between two opposing forces.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A simple mental model for deciding when to emphasize vision/theory vs. execution by treating them as a polarity to balance, not a single optimum.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing vision and execution in practice
quotes.text: we have all the data scientists and PhDs locked in a room for two weeks and there's a beautiful whiteboard diagram. What did it look like? And then it's like, why don't we actually build this thing?
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A concrete example of over-theorizing that practitioners can use as a warning sign: lots of design time without a path to building.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing vision and execution in practice
quotes.text: And it was like, people would be like, "I'm just going to run through a wall. I have no idea if that's the right wall to run through, but at least I know I'm running through a wall."
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A memorable articulation of the failure mode of over-execution—high velocity without sufficient directional clarity.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing vision and execution in practice
quotes.text: So yeah, I think it's about balance and can you adjust. Again, it's dynamic.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: Actionable guidance that the right mix of strategy and execution changes over time and leaders should actively recalibrate.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing vision and execution in practice
quotes.text: And there's times where the strategy and vision's pretty baked at least for the next whatever, six months, a year. And it's like, okay, pedal to the metal. Let's just go execute. Let's get it done.
quotes.speaker: John Mark Nickels
quotes.context: A practical rule of thumb: once direction is sufficiently clear for a time horizon, shift decisively into execution mode.
